Hot Process.name: Homemade Aloe Vera Soap Using the Hot Process Method
ingredients: Aloe Vera (moisturizing, soothing), Tea Tree, Eucalyptus, French Green Clay. Perfect for beginners.
225g rice bran oil (can sub with more olive oil)
200g filtered tap water (or 150g for a harder soap)
Hot Process.instructions:
1. Melt the oils: Add cocoa butter, olive oil, rice bran oil, and coconut oil to a crock pot (HIGH for 5-10 mins) or heavy saucepan (VERY low heat, max 80°C/180°F).
2. Prepare Lye and Aloe: Prepare the lye solution (water + sodium hydroxide, with safety precautions). Prepare 50g of completely blended fresh aloe vera gel.
3. Mix: Blend the clay into the melted oils. Add the lye solution to the oils and stick blend until the batter starts to emulsify.
4. Add Aloe: Add the aloe vera gel and continue to blend until the mixture reaches a very thick consistency (trace).
5. Cook: Cover and cook on low-very low heat for 15-20 minutes until the soap darkens and appears vaseline-ey (gel phase). Test for full saponification with pH strips.
6. Add Essential Oils: Remove from heat, cool for 5-10 minutes (no hotter than 80°C/180°F), and stir in essential oils.
7. Mold and Cure: Spoon the soap into the mould, banging down regularly. Allow to cool and harden for 1-3 days. Remove, cut into bars, and cure/dry for 4 weeks before using.
Hot Process.benefits:
Aloe Vera (moisturizing, soothing), Tea Tree, Eucalyptus, French Green Clay. Perfect for beginners.
Ingredients List:
- Oils (750g total):
    - 75g cocoa butter
    - 300g olive oil
    - 225g rice bran oil (can sub with more olive oil)
    - 150g coconut oil
- Lye Solution:
    - 200g filtered tap water (or 150g for a harder soap)
    - 100g sodium hydroxide/caustic soda
- Additives (Optional):
    - 50g aloe vera gel
    - 20g tea tree essential oil
    - 10g eucalyptus essential oil
    - 3 tsp French green clay
Instructions:
1. Melt the oils: Add cocoa butter, olive oil, rice bran oil, and coconut oil to a crock pot (HIGH for 5-10 mins) or heavy saucepan (VERY low heat, max 80°C/180°F).
2. Prepare Lye and Aloe: Prepare the lye solution (water + sodium hydroxide, with safety precautions). Prepare 50g of completely blended fresh aloe vera gel.
3. Mix: Blend the clay into the melted oils. Add the lye solution to the oils and stick blend until the batter starts to emulsify.
4. Add Aloe: Add the aloe vera gel and continue to blend until the mixture reaches a very thick consistency (trace).
5. Cook: Cover and cook on low-very low heat for 15-20 minutes until the soap darkens and appears vaseline-ey (gel phase). Test for full saponification with pH strips.
6. Add Essential Oils: Remove from heat, cool for 5-10 minutes (no hotter than 80°C/180°F), and stir in essential oils.
7. Mold and Cure: Spoon the soap into the mould, banging down regularly. Allow to cool and harden for 1-3 days. Remove, cut into bars, and cure/dry for 4 weeks before using.

Hot Process.name: Almond Meal Soap
ingredients: 1 tbl intense almond fragrance oil (Note: Synthetic additive)
Hot Process.instructions:
1. Put on protective gear (goggles and gloves).
2. Weigh liquid oils (18oz olive oil, 1 oz castor oil) into the slow cooker.
3. Weigh lye (4.9 oz) and water (11 oz, with some ice cubes recommended).
4. Pour lye into water slowly and stir to dissolve. Set aside to cool.
5. Weigh and melt solid fats (8 oz coconut oil, 6 oz palm oil, 2 oz shea butter).
6. Pour melted solid fats into the liquid oils in the slow cooker and mix.
7. Pour lye water slowly and carefully into the oil while stirring.
8. Use a stick blender to stir until it reaches a thin pudding/gravy consistency ("trace").
9. Set the slow cooker to "low," put the lid on. Check after 15 minutes for separation and mix if needed.
10. Check again in 20-30 minutes. The mixture will start to turn translucent from the edges inward.
11. Stir the translucent mixture every 20-30 minutes. It will look like apple sauce. Mix in the floating glycerin layer.
12. After 1.5 - 2 hours of cooking and stirring, the mixture will have a Vaseline-like consistency and is neutral. Turn off the slow cooker.
13. Add 5-6 tbls of almond meal and 1 tbl of intense almond fragrance oil. Mix well.
14. Scoop the soap into the mold, banging the mold to remove air pockets. Work quickly.
15. Once cool and firm, remove from the mold and cut. The soap can be used immediately.
Hot Process.benefits: Almond meal (exfoliating), Olive oil, Coconut oil, Palm oil, Shea butter, Castor oil (moisturizing/conditioning oils). Note: Contains "intense almond fragrance oil" which is a synthetic additive.

Cold Process.name: Simple Natural Homemade Soap
ingredients: Gentle, skin-conditioning (olive oil), adds hardness and bubbles (coconut oil), promotes better lather (castor oil), suitable for sensitive skin.
Coconut Oil (or Babassu Oil): 2.5 oz (71 g) (15.6%)
Food Grade Lye (6% superfat): 2.14 oz (60 g)
Cold Process.instructions:
1. Make the Lye Solution: Weigh water and lye separately. Sprinkle lye into water (never reverse) and stir until dissolved. Work in a well-ventilated area. Set aside to cool to around 90-100°F (32-38°C).
2. Weigh and Heat the Oils: Weigh coconut oil and melt it. Weigh olive and castor oils into a separate pot. Pour melted coconut oil into the other oils to bring the temperature to around 90-100°F.
3. Combine and Mix Until Trace: Pour the lye solution into the warm oils. Use a stick blender to mix in alternating short bursts until "trace" is reached (when the batter is thick enough to leave an imprint). Add essential oils (optional) at this stage.
4. Pour Into Mold: Pour the batter into the mold. Cover gently with freezer paper, then a blanket/towel to hold heat. After 24 hours, remove the cover. Unmold after 2-3 days or when firm.
5. Cure and Enjoy!: Slice into bars and cure in open air for at least 4 to 6 weeks.
Cold Process.benefits:
Gentle, skin-conditioning (olive oil), adds hardness and bubbles (coconut oil), promotes better lather (castor oil), suitable for sensitive skin.
Ingredients:
- Olive Oil: 12 oz (340 g) (75%)
- Coconut Oil (or Babassu Oil): 2.5 oz (71 g) (15.6%)
- Castor Oil: 1.5 oz (43 g) (9.4%)
- Food Grade Lye (6% superfat): 2.14 oz (60 g)
- Distilled Water: 4.5 oz (128 g)
Instructions:
1. Make the Lye Solution: Weigh water and lye separately. Sprinkle lye into water (never reverse) and stir until dissolved. Work in a well-ventilated area. Set aside to cool to around 90-100°F (32-38°C).
2. Weigh and Heat the Oils: Weigh coconut oil and melt it. Weigh olive and castor oils into a separate pot. Pour melted coconut oil into the other oils to bring the temperature to around 90-100°F.
3. Combine and Mix Until Trace: Pour the lye solution into the warm oils. Use a stick blender to mix in alternating short bursts until "trace" is reached (when the batter is thick enough to leave an imprint). Add essential oils (optional) at this stage.
4. Pour Into Mold: Pour the batter into the mold. Cover gently with freezer paper, then a blanket/towel to hold heat. After 24 hours, remove the cover. Unmold after 2-3 days or when firm.
5. Cure and Enjoy!: Slice into bars and cure in open air for at least 4 to 6 weeks.

Cold Process.name: 34. Tropical Paradise Tropical colors and motifs.
ingredients: green, blue, yellow, pink, and orange)
1. Prepare your workspace by setting out all
materials and tools. Make sure the area is
Cold Process.instructions:
2. Cut the melt and pour soap base into small,
even pieces for easier melting.
3. Place the soap base pieces into a
microwave-safe container. Microwave in 30second intervals, stirring between each
interval, until fully melted.
4. Divide the melted soap base into separate
mixing bowls based on the number of colors
you plan to use.
5. Add a few drops of different colorants to
each bowl, stirring well until the colors are
evenly mixed. Adjust the amount of colorant
to achieve the desired intensity.
6. Add a few drops of fragrance oil to each
bowl and stir well to combine.
7. Pour the first layer of colored soap into the
silicone mold, filling it about one-third full.
Lightly spray the surface with rubbing
alcohol to remove any bubbles.
8. Allow the first layer to cool and form a
skin, which usually takes about 10-15
minutes.
9. Pour the second layer of a different color
on top of the first, repeating the process of
spraying with rubbing alcohol to eliminate
bubbles.
10. Continue layering the colors, allowing
each layer to cool slightly before adding the
next, until the mold is filled.
11. Let the soap fully harden, which typically
takes a few hours. Once hardened, carefully
remove the soap from the mold.
12. Use a knife to trim any excess or uneven
edges if necessary.
Useful tips
- To create swirls or more intricate designs,
use a toothpick or skewer to gently drag
through the layers before they harden
completely.
- If you want to add embeds like small soap
shapes or botanicals, place them in the mold
before pouring the soap base, and ensure they
are securely covered with the melted soap.
- Using a transparent soap base can give a
more vibrant and translucent effect to the
tropical colors.
- Always work in a well-ventilated area and
wear protective gloves to avoid skin irritation
from fragrance oils and colorants.
- Experiment with different color
combinations and layering techniques to
achieve unique and beautiful tropical designs.
35. Fairy Tale - Magical and
enchanted elements.
Materials and tools needed:
- clear melt and pour soap base
- soap colorants (pastel and shimmering
colors)
- soap fragrance oils (like lavender, vanilla, or
jasmine)
- soap mold (fairy tale shapes like stars,
moons, castles)
- biodegradable glitter
- dried flower petals (optional)
- small mixing bowls
- stirring sticks
- rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- microwave-safe container
- knife
- cutting board
Procedure:
1. prepare the soap base by cutting it into
small cubes for easier melting.
2. place the soap cubes into a microwave-safe
container and melt in the microwave in 30second intervals, stirring between each
interval until fully melted.
3. divide the melted soap base into small
mixing bowls based on the number of colors
you want to use.
4. add a few drops of soap colorant to each
bowl and mix well until you achieve the
desired shades. For a fairy tale theme, pastel
and shimmering colors work best.
5. add a few drops of fragrance oil to each
bowl and stir thoroughly.
6. pour a thin layer of one colored soap into
the soap mold. Let it set until a thin skin
forms on top.
7. spray a light mist of rubbing alcohol over
the layer to remove any bubbles.
8. sprinkle a small amount of biodegradable
glitter or dried flower petals over the layer if
desired.
9. repeat steps 6 to 8 with different colors,
creating layers and enchanting effects. Allow
each layer to form a skin and spray with
rubbing alcohol before adding the next.
10. once the mold is filled, let the soap sit and
fully harden for several hours or overnight.
11. carefully unmold the soap by gently
pressing on the mold to release the shapes.
12. use a knife to trim any rough edges and
smooth the surface of the soap if needed.
Useful tips:
- work in a well-ventilated area to avoid
inhaling fragrance fumes.
- use rubbing alcohol between layers to
prevent them from separating.
- for added magic, embed small fairy talethemed soap embeds (like tiny stars or
moons) between layers.
- keep the melted soap base warm to avoid it
setting too quickly while you work.
- experiment with different color
combinations and layering techniques to
create unique designs.
- store the finished soap in a cool, dry place to
maintain its quality and appearance.
36. Vintage - Vintage effect
with classic colors and motifs.
Materials and Tools Needed
- Soap base (clear or white)
- Classic colorants (e.g., sepia, muted pastels,
antique gold)
- Vintage-inspired fragrance oils (e.g.,
lavender, rose, sandalwood)
- Soap mold (preferably with vintage
patterns)
- Mixing bowls
- Microwave or double boiler
- Spatula
- Alcohol in a spray bottle (to remove
bubbles)
- Thermometer
- Stirring sticks
- Gloves
- Protective eyewear
Procedure
1. Cut the soap base into small, even pieces
and place them in a microwave-safe bowl or
double boiler.
2. Heat the soap base until it is completely
melted, monitoring the temperature to avoid
overheating (ideal temperature is around
130°F).
3. Once melted, add classic colorants
gradually. Mix well to achieve a uniform
color reminiscent of vintage tones.
4. Add a few drops of vintage-inspired
fragrance oils and stir thoroughly to blend the
scent evenly.
5. Pour a thin layer of the colored soap into
the mold, filling it about one-third of the way.
Spray with alcohol to eliminate any bubbles.
6. Let this layer cool slightly until it starts to
harden but is still somewhat pliable.
7. Prepare another portion of soap base with a
different vintage color. Pour this new layer
over the first one, spraying alcohol again to
prevent bubbles.
8. Repeat this process to create multiple
layers, each with a different vintage color,
until the mold is filled.
9. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely, usually taking several hours or
overnight.
10. Once fully hardened, carefully remove the
soap from the mold.
Useful Tips
- Use muted and dusty colorants to achieve a
true vintage look.
- To create intricate patterns, you can use
vintage-themed stamps or embed small
vintage-inspired objects within the soap
layers.
- Mixing a small amount of white soap base
with colorants can help achieve pastel shades,
which are characteristic of vintage styles.
- Keep the soap layers thin to create a more
delicate and refined vintage appearance.
- Ensure the work area is well-ventilated
when working with fragrance oils and melted
soap base.
- Always wear protective gloves and eyewear
to avoid any accidents while handling hot
soap.
37. Monochrome - Single color
with various shades.
Materials and Tools Needed
- Soap base (clear or white)
- Soap colorant (one color)
- Soap mold
- Mixing bowls
- Microwave or double boiler
- Stirring utensils
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- Measuring spoons
- Thermometer
Procedure
1. Cut the soap base into small, even chunks
and place them in a microwave-safe bowl.
2. Melt the soap base in the microwave in 30second intervals, stirring between each
interval until fully melted. Alternatively, use a
double boiler to melt the soap base.
3. Divide the melted soap into several bowls,
depending on how many shades you want to
create.
4. Add different amounts of soap colorant to
each bowl to create varying shades of the
same color. Start with a small amount and
gradually add more until you achieve the
desired shades.
5. Stir each bowl thoroughly to ensure the
color is evenly distributed.
6. Begin pouring the soap into the mold,
starting with the darkest shade.
7. Allow the first layer to cool slightly until it
forms a thin skin on the surface.
8. Spray the layer with rubbing alcohol to
remove any bubbles and help the next layer
adhere.
9. Pour the next shade of soap gently over the
first layer. Repeat the process, allowing each
layer to cool slightly and spraying with
rubbing alcohol before adding the next layer.
10. Continue layering the soap in this manner
until all shades have been used.
11. Let the soap fully cool and harden in the
mold for several hours or overnight.
12. Once the soap is fully set, remove it from
the mold and cut it into bars if necessary.
Useful Tips
- Use a thermometer to ensure the soap base
does not overheat, as this can cause it to
become too hot and affect the layering
process.
- If the layers start to blend too much, allow
the previous layer to cool a bit longer before
adding the next one.
- Experiment with the amount of colorant to
achieve subtle or dramatic differences in
shades.
- Use clear soap base for a translucent effect
or white soap base for a more opaque look.
- To speed up the cooling process, place the
mold in the refrigerator for a few minutes
between layers.
38. Candy Cane - Red and
white stripes like candy canes.
Materials and tools needed
- Melt and pour soap base
- Red soap colorant
- White soap colorant (optional, if the soap
base is not white)
- Peppermint essential oil (optional, for
fragrance)
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- Microwave-safe containers
- Mixing spoons
- Soap mold
- Thermometer
- Measuring cups
Procedure
1. Cut the melt and pour soap base into small,
even chunks. Divide the chunks into two
microwave-safe containers.
2. Heat one container in the microwave in 30second intervals until fully melted, stirring
between intervals. This will be your white
layer. If your soap base is not white, add
white soap colorant until the desired color is
achieved.
3. Once melted, add a few drops of
peppermint essential oil if desired. Stir well to
combine.
4. Pour a thin layer of the white soap into the
soap mold. Spritz the surface lightly with
rubbing alcohol to remove any bubbles. Let
this layer cool and harden slightly, but not
completely.
5. While the white layer is setting, melt the
second container of soap base in the
microwave. Once melted, add red soap
colorant until you achieve a vibrant red color.
Add peppermint essential oil if desired and
stir well.
6. Once the white layer has set slightly, pour a
thin layer of the red soap over it. Spritz with
rubbing alcohol to remove bubbles. Let this
layer cool and harden slightly.
7. Repeat the layering process, alternating
between white and red layers, until the soap
mold is filled. Spritz each layer with rubbing
alcohol to remove bubbles and help the layers
adhere to each other.
8. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely at room temperature, or place it in
the refrigerator for faster setting.
9. Once fully hardened, carefully remove the
soap from the mold and cut it into bars.
Useful tips
- Ensure each layer is slightly set but not fully
hardened before pouring the next layer. This
will help the layers adhere better without
bleeding into each other.
- Use a thermometer to ensure the soap is not
too hot when pouring layers, as high
temperatures can cause the colors to bleed.
- Spritzing each layer with rubbing alcohol
helps to eliminate bubbles and promotes
better adhesion between layers.
- Experiment with the thickness of each layer
to achieve different stripe patterns.
- Store your candy cane soap in a cool, dry
place to prevent sweating and maintain its
vibrant colors.
39. Ethereal - Light and
translucent patterns.
Materials and tools needed:
- clear melt and pour soap base
- soap colorants (preferably pastel shades)
- mica powder for shimmer
- fragrance oil (optional)
- soap mold
- microwave-safe bowl
- stirring stick or spoon
- rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- pipette or dropper
Procedure:
1. Cut the clear melt and pour soap base
into small, uniform pieces to ensure even
melting.
2. Place the soap base pieces in a
microwave-safe bowl and heat in the
microwave in 20-30 second intervals,
stirring in between, until completely
melted.
3. Add a few drops of soap colorant to the
melted soap base. Use pastel shades to
achieve a light and ethereal look. Stir
gently to combine.
4. Add a pinch of mica powder for a
shimmering effect. Stir well to distribute
evenly.
5. If desired, add a few drops of fragrance
oil to the mixture and stir to combine.
6. Using a pipette or dropper, carefully
pour the colored soap mixture into the
soap mold, creating light and translucent
patterns. For a more ethereal effect, pour
in layers, allowing each layer to set
slightly before adding the next.
7. Spray the surface of the soap with
rubbing alcohol to remove any bubbles
that may have formed.
8. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely, which may take a few hours or
overnight.
9. Once the soap is fully set, gently
remove it from the mold.
Useful tips:
- To create more intricate patterns, use a
toothpick or skewer to swirl the colors
gently before the soap sets.
- Experiment with different pastel shades
and mica powders to achieve unique
ethereal effects.
- Ensure that the soap base is not
overheated, as this can cause the colors to
become too dark and lose the ethereal
quality.
- Use clear soap molds to better visualize
the patterns as you pour and layer the soap
mixture.
- If you are new to soap making, start with
smaller batches to practice the technique
before creating larger quantities.
40. Fruit Burst - Pieces of
colored fruit.
Materials and tools needed
- Clear melt and pour soap base
- Soap colorants (various colors)
- Fragrance oil (optional)
- Small soap molds (fruit shapes)
- Large soap mold
- Spray bottle with rubbing alcohol
- Knife
- Microwave-safe containers
- Stirring sticks
Procedure
1. Begin by creating the small fruit pieces.
Melt a portion of the clear soap base in a
microwave-safe container in 30-second
intervals until fully melted.
2. Add soap colorant to the melted base and
stir well to achieve the desired color. Pour the
colored soap into the small fruit-shaped
molds and let it set completely.
3. Once the fruit pieces are hardened,
carefully remove them from the molds and set
them aside.
4. Melt more of the clear soap base in a
microwave-safe container.
5. Add a few drops of fragrance oil if desired
and stir well.
6. Pour a thin layer of the melted clear soap
base into the large soap mold and spritz with
rubbing alcohol to remove any bubbles.
7. Place the small fruit pieces on top of the
thin layer in the large mold. Arrange them as
desired, ensuring they are evenly distributed.
8. Melt additional clear soap base and pour it
over the fruit pieces in the large mold, filling
it to the top. Spritz with rubbing alcohol to
remove any bubbles.
9. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely, which may take a few hours.
10. Once fully set, remove the soap from the
mold and cut it into bars as desired.
Useful tips
- Make sure the fruit pieces are completely set
before embedding them in the large mold to
prevent them from melting or deforming.
- Spritzing with rubbing alcohol helps to
eliminate air bubbles and create a smooth
finish.
- Experiment with different colors and shapes
for the fruit pieces to create a variety of
designs.
- If the small fruit pieces start to float when
you pour the clear base, allow the base to cool
slightly before pouring so it is thicker and can
better support the pieces.
- Store the soap in a cool, dry place to
maintain its appearance and scent.
41. Zen Garden - Relaxing and
minimalist patterns.
Materials and tools needed
- Soap base (e.g., glycerin or shea butter)
- Essential oils (e.g., lavender, eucalyptus, or
sandalwood)
- Soap colorants (earthy tones like green,
beige, or grey)
- Soap mold (rectangular or square shapes are
ideal)
- Mixing bowls
- Measuring spoons
- Silicone spatula
- Alcohol spray
- Droppers
- Fine sand or small pebbles (optional for
decoration)
- Bamboo skewer or toothpick
Procedure
1. Cut the soap base into small cubes and melt
it in a double boiler or microwave, stirring
occasionally until fully melted.
2. Add a few drops of essential oils to the
melted soap base, stirring gently to mix the
fragrance evenly.
3. Divide the melted soap into separate bowls
if you are using multiple colors. Add the soap
colorants to each bowl, mixing well to
achieve the desired shades.
4. Pour a thin layer of one color into the soap
mold and let it cool slightly until a thin skin
forms on top.
5. Using a bamboo skewer or toothpick,
gently draw wavy lines or patterns in the
partially set soap layer to create a raked sand
effect. This will be the first layer of your Zen
garden design.
6. Pour the next layer of a different color over
the first layer, repeating the process of letting
it cool slightly and then drawing patterns with
the skewer or toothpick.
7. Continue layering and drawing patterns
until the mold is filled, alternating colors and
creating a harmonious, minimalist design.
8. If desired, gently press fine sand or small
pebbles into the top layer of the soap for
additional texture and a more authentic Zen
garden appearance.
9. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely in the mold, which may take
several hours or overnight.
10. Once fully set, carefully remove the soap
from the mold and cut it into bars if using a
large mold.
Useful tips
- Use calming essential oils to enhance the
relaxing nature of the Zen garden design.
- Work quickly but carefully when drawing
patterns in the partially set soap to avoid
breaking the surface.
- For a more natural look, use soap colorants
in muted, earthy tones.
- Spraying each layer with alcohol before
pouring the next layer can help the layers
adhere better and reduce bubbles.
- Experiment with different patterns and
textures to create a unique and personalized
Zen garden soap.
This technique will help you create a
beautiful and calming Zen garden soap with
minimalist patterns that evoke tranquility and
relaxation.
42. Winter Wonderland Colors and glitter reminiscent
of winter.
Materials and tools needed
- Clear melt and pour soap base
- White melt and pour soap base
- Blue soap colorant
- Silver and blue cosmetic-grade glitter
- Snowflake silicone mold or regular soap
mold
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- Microwave-safe containers
- Stirring sticks
- Knife
- Cutting board
Procedure
1. Cut the clear melt and pour soap base into
small cubes and place them in a microwavesafe container. Microwave in 30-second
intervals until completely melted.
2. Add a few drops of blue soap colorant to
the melted clear soap base and stir until the
color is evenly distributed.
3. Pour the blue soap base into the mold,
filling it halfway. Spray with rubbing alcohol
to remove any bubbles. Let it cool and harden
slightly.
4. In another microwave-safe container, melt
the white melt and pour soap base in 30second intervals until fully melted.
5. Sprinkle silver and blue glitter into the
mold on top of the slightly hardened blue
layer.
6. Pour the melted white soap base over the
glitter layer. Spray with rubbing alcohol to
remove bubbles. Let it cool completely.
7. Once fully cooled and hardened, remove
the soap from the mold.
8. If using a regular soap mold, cut the soap
into bars as desired.
Useful tips
- To enhance the winter effect, you can add a
few drops of peppermint or eucalyptus
essential oil to the white soap base for a
refreshing scent.
- Make sure each layer cools slightly before
pouring the next one to avoid mixing the
colors.
- Use cosmetic-grade glitter to ensure it is
safe for skin contact.
- If you want a more detailed winter
wonderland look, consider using a snowflake
or winter-themed silicone mold.
43. Underwater - Patterns
reminiscent of the underwater
world.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Clear glycerin soap base
- Blue and green soap dye
- Soap fragrance oil (optional)
- Soap mold with underwater-themed shapes
(e.g., fish, seashells, seaweed)
- Microwave-safe bowl
- Spoon for stirring
- Spray bottle with rubbing alcohol
- Knife or soap cutter
Procedure:
1. Cut the clear glycerin soap base into small
cubes and place them in a microwave-safe
bowl.
2. Microwave the soap base in 30-second
intervals until completely melted, stirring
between each interval.
3. Add a few drops of blue and green soap
dye to the melted soap base, adjusting the
amount to achieve the desired underwater
colors.
4. If desired, add a few drops of soap
fragrance oil to the melted soap base and stir
well to combine.
5. Spray the soap mold with rubbing alcohol
to prevent bubbles from forming.
6. Pour a small amount of the colored soap
into the mold to create the first layer.
7. Allow the first layer to set slightly, then add
any underwater-themed shapes (e.g., fish,
seashells, seaweed) into the mold.
8. Pour the remaining colored soap over the
shapes to cover them completely.
9. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely, which typically takes 1-2 hours.
10. Once the soap is fully hardened, carefully
remove it from the mold.
11. Use a knife or soap cutter to cut the soap
into individual bars, if necessary.
Useful Tips:
- To create a more realistic underwater effect,
consider adding small pieces of seaweed or
sandalwood powder to the soap base before
pouring it into the mold.
- Experiment with different colors and shapes
to create unique underwater scenes in each
bar of soap.
- For added visual interest, consider using a
clear soap base for the underwater
background and a colored soap base for the
underwater-themed shapes.
44. Feather - Feather-like and
delicate patterns.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Soap base
- Feather-shaped soap mold
- Soap colorants (various colors)
- Essential oils or fragrance oils
- Rubbing alcohol (in a spray bottle)
- Small mixing bowls
- Stirring sticks
- Soap cutter
- Microwave or double boiler
- Work surface covered with parchment paper
Procedure:
1. Begin by melting the soap base in a
microwave or double boiler until it is
completely melted and smooth.
2. Divide the melted soap base into different
small mixing bowls, one for each color you
plan to use.
3. Add soap colorants to each bowl to achieve
the desired colors, stirring well to ensure they
are evenly mixed.
4. Add a few drops of essential oils or
fragrance oils to each bowl for scent, if
desired.
5. Spray the feather-shaped soap mold with
rubbing alcohol to help the soap adhere.
6. Pour a thin layer of one color of soap into
the bottom of the mold and allow it to set
slightly.
7. Using a spoon or dropper, carefully add
small dots or lines of different colored soap
on top of the first layer. The colors should
resemble the delicate patterns of a feather.
8. Continue layering different colors and
patterns until the mold is full, ensuring each
layer is set slightly before adding the next.
9. Once the mold is full, spray the top of the
soap with rubbing alcohol to remove any air
bubbles.
10. Allow the soap to fully harden and cool,
usually for several hours or overnight.
11. Once hardened, gently remove the soap
from the mold and cut into bars using a soap
cutter.
12. Allow the bars to cure for a few weeks
before using or packaging.
Useful Tips:
- Work quickly when pouring and layering the
soap to prevent it from hardening too much.
- Experiment with different colors and
patterns to create unique feather-like designs.
- Clean the soap mold thoroughly between
uses to prevent colors from mixing.
45. Camo - Camouflage
pattern.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Soap base (clear or opaque)
- Soap colorants (green, brown, beige)
- Soap mold
- Knife or spatula
- Microwave or double boiler
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- Small cups for mixing colors
Procedure:
1. Cut the soap base into small cubes and melt
it in the microwave or a double boiler
according to the manufacturer's instructions.
2. Divide the melted soap base into three
equal parts in separate containers.
3. Add green colorant to one container, brown
colorant to another, and beige colorant to the
third. Mix each color thoroughly.
4. Pour a small amount of the green soap into
the mold, followed by the brown and beige,
creating random layers.
5. Use a knife or spatula to gently swirl the
colors together, creating a camouflage
pattern. Be careful not to overmix.
6. Let the soap cool and harden for several
hours or until completely set.
7. Once the soap is firm, remove it from the
mold and cut it into bars.
8. Spray the soap with rubbing alcohol to
remove any air bubbles and smooth the
surface.
Useful Tips:
- Work quickly when pouring and swirling the
colors to prevent the soap from hardening
before you're finished.
- Experiment with different color
combinations and swirling techniques to
achieve the desired camouflage effect.
- Allow the soap to cure for at least 4 weeks
before using it to ensure it is firm and longlasting.
46. Aurora Borealis - Colors
reminiscent of the aurora
borealis.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Clear melt-and-pour soap base
- Various colors of mica powders (blues,
greens, purples)
- Soap molds
- Spray bottle with rubbing alcohol
- Heat-safe containers
- Stirring utensils
- Knife or soap cutter
Procedure:
1. Cut the clear melt-and-pour soap base into
small cubes and melt it in a heat-safe
container following the manufacturer's
instructions.
2. Once melted, divide the soap base into
separate containers for each color you'll use.
3. Mix different colors of mica powders into
each container to create the vibrant colors of
the aurora borealis.
4. Pour a thin layer of one color into the
bottom of the soap mold and spray it with
rubbing alcohol to remove any air bubbles.
5. Repeat the process with each color,
layering them in the mold to create a
multicolored effect.
6. Continue layering and spraying with
alcohol between layers until the mold is full.
7. Let the soap cool and harden completely
before removing it from the mold.
8. Once hardened, carefully remove the soap
from the mold and cut it into bars or shapes as
desired.
Useful Tips:
- Work quickly when pouring and layering the
soap to prevent it from hardening before
you're finished.
- Experiment with different color
combinations and layering techniques to
achieve the desired aurora borealis effect.
- Use a dropper to create swirls or patterns in
the soap for a more dynamic design.
47. Rainy Day - Shades of gray
with hints of blue.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Soap base
- Gray soap colorant
- Blue soap colorant
- Soap mold
- Fragrance oil (optional)
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
Procedure:
1. Melt the soap base according to the
manufacturer's instructions.
2. Add the gray soap colorant to achieve the
desired shade of gray.
3. Pour a thin layer of the gray soap into the
mold and let it set slightly.
4. Spritz the surface with rubbing alcohol to
remove any air bubbles.
5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 until you've reached
the desired thickness for the gray layer.
6. Once the gray layers are set, prepare a new
batch of melted soap base.
7. Add a small amount of blue soap colorant
to create a light blue hue.
8. Pour the blue soap over the gray layers in a
random pattern to resemble raindrops.
9. Allow the soap to fully harden and cool in
the mold.
10. Once completely set, remove the soap
from the mold and cut into bars if necessary.
Useful Tips:
- Experiment with different shades of gray
and blue to create a more realistic rainy day
effect.
- Use a dropper or small spoon to create
varied droplet sizes for a natural look.
- Adding a rain-inspired fragrance oil, such as
"Ocean Rain" or "Fresh Linen," can enhance
the theme of the soap design.
48. Tartan - Scottish tartan
pattern.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Soap base
- Soap colorants in desired tartan colors (e.g.,
red, green, blue, yellow)
- Soap mold with square or rectangular
sections
- Knife or soap cutter
- Heat-safe containers for melting soap base
- Stirrers or spoons for mixing colors
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle (optional)
Procedure:
1. Begin by cutting the soap base into small,
uniform cubes to facilitate melting.
2. In separate heat-safe containers, melt the
soap base using a microwave or double boiler
method.
3. Once melted, add soap colorants to each
container to achieve the desired tartan colors.
Stir well to ensure even distribution.
4. Pour a small amount of one colored soap
into the mold, enough to cover the bottom of
one section.
5. Allow the soap to cool and harden slightly,
but not completely.
6. Using a knife or spatula, create diagonal
lines across the soap section, dividing it into
triangles.
7. Pour the next colored soap into the mold,
filling in the sections adjacent to the first
color.
8. Repeat the process of creating diagonal
lines in the new section, but in the opposite
direction to the first lines, creating a
crisscross pattern.
9. Continue alternating colors and creating
diagonal lines until the mold is filled.
10. Allow the soap to cool and harden
completely before removing it from the mold.
11. Once removed, cut the soap along the
lines to separate the tartan pattern into
individual bars.
Useful Tips:
- Work quickly when pouring and creating
lines to prevent the soap from hardening too
much.
- Use rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle to
eliminate air bubbles that may form on the
surface of the soap.
- Experiment with different color
combinations and patterns to create unique
tartan designs.
49. Mosaic - Small pieces of
different colors.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Soap base
- Soap dyes or colorants in various colors
- Soap molds
- Knife or soap cutter
- Cutting board
- Microwave or double boiler
- Stirring utensil
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle
- Plastic wrap or parchment paper
Procedure:
1. Begin by preparing your soap base
according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Melt the soap base using a microwave or
double boiler.
2. Once melted, separate the soap into smaller
containers. Add soap dyes or colorants to
each container to create different colored
soaps.
3. Pour each colored soap into separate molds
and allow them to harden completely.
4. Once the soap has hardened, remove it
from the molds and place it on a cutting
board.
5. Using a knife or soap cutter, carefully cut
the colored soap into small pieces of varying
shapes and sizes.
6. Prepare your main soap mold by lining it
with plastic wrap or parchment paper.
7. Arrange the small pieces of colored soap in
the main mold, creating a mosaic pattern.
Press the pieces gently into the mold to secure
them in place.
8. Melt any remaining clear soap base and
pour it over the mosaic pattern in the main
mold. This will help bind the pieces together.
9. Allow the soap to harden completely before
removing it from the mold.
10. Once the soap has hardened, carefully
remove it from the mold and cut it into bars
or desired shapes.
11. Allow the soap to cure for a few weeks
before using it.
Useful Tips:
- Work quickly when arranging the mosaic
pieces, as the melted soap base can harden
fast.
- Use a variety of colors and shapes to create
a more intricate mosaic pattern.
- Spray rubbing alcohol between layers of
soap to help them adhere together.
- Experiment with different color
combinations and arrangements to create
unique mosaic designs.
50. Cosmic - Vibrant colors
with glitter for a cosmic effect.
Materials and Tools Needed:
- Clear melt and pour soap base
- Vibrant soap colorants (e.g., neon or cosmic
colors)
- Biodegradable cosmetic glitter
- Soap mold (with cosmic or star shapes, if
desired)
- Microwave-safe measuring cup
- Stirring utensil
- Rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle (optional,
for removing air bubbles)
Procedure:
1. Cut the clear melt and pour soap base into
small, uniform cubes and place them in a
microwave-safe measuring cup.
2. Microwave the soap base in short bursts,
stirring in between, until completely melted.
3. Add a few drops of vibrant soap colorants
to the melted soap base and stir until the
desired color is achieved. Be careful not to
add too much colorant, as it can affect the
soap's ability to lather.
4. Pour a thin layer of the colored soap into
the soap mold and allow it to cool and harden
slightly. This will be the first layer of your
cosmic design.
5. Once the first layer has set, sprinkle a small
amount of biodegradable cosmetic glitter onto
the surface of the soap.
6. Pour another layer of colored soap over the
glitter and allow it to cool and harden slightly.
7. Repeat the process of adding glitter and
pouring colored soap layers until the mold is
filled.
8. Allow the soap to fully harden and cool
before removing it from the mold.
9. If desired, you can use rubbing alcohol in a
spray bottle to remove any air bubbles that
may have formed in the soap while pouring
the layers.
Useful Tips:
- Experiment with different color
combinations and amounts of glitter to
achieve the desired cosmic effect.
- To create a more pronounced cosmic effect,
consider using a soap mold with cosmic or
star shapes.
- Allow each layer of soap to cool and harden
slightly before adding the next layer to
prevent the colors from blending together.
- Be mindful of the amount of glitter you use,
as using too much can make the soap feel
gritty.

Cold Process.name: Alpine Swirl Cold Process Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["Avocado Oil - 1 lb", "Coconut Oil - 1 lb", "Olive Oil - Pure - 1 lb", "Rice Bran Oil - 1 lb", "Castor Oil - 1 lb", "Sodium Hydroxide Lye", "Fresh Snow Fragrance Oil - 1.75 oz", "Titanium Dioxide Pigment - 1 oz", "Palm Oil - 1 lb", "Cobalt Blue Mica - 1 oz", "Stormy Blue Mica - 1 oz"]
Cold Process.instructions: 1. Slowly and carefully add 4.9 ounces of lye to 10.4 ounces of distilled water. Gently stir until the lye has fully dissolved. Set it aside to cool. If you’d like a harder bar of soap that releases faster from the mold, you can add sodium lactate to the cooled lye water. Use 1 teaspoon of sodium lactate per pound of oils in the recipe. For this recipe, you’d add 2 teaspoons sodium lactate.\n2. Melt and combine 3.5 ounces of avocado oil, 1 ounce of castor oil, 8.8 ounces of coconut oil, 8.8 ounces of olive oil, 8.8 ounces of palm oil (remember to fully melt the entire container of palm oil before portioning), and 4.2 ounces of rice bran oil into a large mixing bowl. Once the lye water and the oils have cooled to 130 degrees F or below (and are ideally within 10 degrees of each other), add the lye water to the oils and stick blend the mixture to a very thin trace.

Cold Process.name: Carrot Cold Process Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["2 oz. Carrot Seed Oil 5%", "1.2 oz. Castor Oil 3%", "2.4 oz. Deodorized Cocoa Butter 6%", "10 oz. Coconut Oil 25%", "13.6 oz. Olive Oil 34%", "10.8 oz. Palm Oil 27%", "5.6 oz. Sodium Hydroxide Lye", "13.2 oz. Distilled Water", "2 oz. Avocado Fragrance Oil", "0.6 oz. Orange 10X Essential Oil", "Nuclear Orange Pigment", "Brown Oxide", "Walnut Shells", "Orange Peel Powder"]
Cold Process.instructions:
*SCULPTING TOOL PREP:* First, you need to create the tool for the carrot shape. Cut a piece of sturdy cardboard into a “T” shape. Then, draw a carrot shape and cut it out. Ours ended up being about 2.5″ long from the bottom of the carrot to the top. Keep in mind that the exact size and shape doesn’t really matter. You can make it larger or smaller if you like. The top sides of the piece of cardboard will rest on top of either side of the mold. This will help keep the tool level throughout the process. If you’d like, you can also include a “lip” on the side (as seen in this tutorial). Because the carrot shape is less complicated and doesn’t need to be as precise, we didn’t include it. Once you’re happy with the size and shape of the carrot, wrap it in clear packaging tape. This helps make it stronger and more “soap-proof” as it’s moved throughout the mold.

* MOLD & TOOL PREP:* Line the Tall Narrow Wood Loaf Mold with freezer paper with the shiny side up. For tips on how to line the mold, click here.

* FRAGRANCE PREP:* Measure 2 ounces of Avocado Fragrance Oil into a small glass container and set aside. Measure 0.6 ounces of 10X Orange Essential Oil into a separate small glass container and set aside.

* COLORANT PREP:* Disperse 1 teaspoon of the brown oxide into 1 tablespoon of sunflower or sweet almond oil (or any other liquid oil). Then disperse 1 teaspoon of Nuclear Orange Pigment into 1 tablespoon of lightweight liquid oil. Use a mini mixer to get rid of any clumps. Have 2 tablespoons of walnut shells and 2 teaspoons of orange peel powder nearby.

* SAFETY FIRST:* Suit up for safe handling practices. That means goggles, gloves, and long sleeves. Make sure kids, pets, other distractions, and tripping hazards are out of the house or don’t have access to your soaping space. Always soap in a well-ventilated area.

* Slowly and carefully add 5.6 ounces of lye to 13.2 ounces of distilled water and gently stir until the lye has fully dissolved and the liquid is clear. Set aside to cool. If you’d like a harder bar of soap that releases faster from the mold, you can add sodium lactate to the cooled lye water. Use 1 teaspoon of sodium lactate per pound of oils in the recipe. For this recipe, you’d add 2.5 teaspoons sodium lactate.

* Melt and combine 2 ounces of carrot seed oil, 1.2 ounces of castor oil, 2.4 ounces of deodorized cocoa butter, 10 ounces of coconut oil, 13.6 ounces of olive oil, and 10.8 ounces of palm oil (remember to fully melt then mix your entire container of palm oil before portioning) into a large mixing bowl.

* Once the lye and water have cooled to about 130 degrees F, split off 10 ounces of the oil mixture into a separate container. Then, very carefully (with safety gear on), pour off 4.7 ounces of the lye solution into a separate container. Set these aside – they will be mixed together to form the carrot.

* Slowly add the large batch of lye solution to the large batch of oils and stick blend until thin trace.

* Add the 2 ounces of Avocado Fragrance Oil and use the stick blender to mix it in.

* Add all of the dispersed brown oxide and 2 tablespoons of walnut shells. Use a whisk to mix them in thoroughly.

* The soap should be a thin-medium trace. Give it a few pulses with the stick blender if it’s still quite thin. Pour all of the brown soap into the Tall Narrow Wood Loaf Mold. Tap the mold firmly on the counter to get rid of bubbles.

* Now, it’s time to wait for the soap to firm and harden. The soap should be firm enough to hold its shape but thin enough to be scraped out smoothly. It’s a little hard to know when you have that “perfect” texture. We tested every 3 minutes or so by scraping a small amount of the very top of the soap with the carrot tool. It’s better to start scraping out the extra soap sooner rather than later. If the soap is not thick enough to hold any shape, let it harden for a few more minutes. But, if the soap is too thick, there is no going back. For this recipe, we found waiting about 8-10 minutes was the perfect amount of time to start carving out the carrot. Your soap may require more or less time, so keep an eye on it.

* Once the soap is an appropriate texture, insert the cardboard carrot shape and begin pulling it through the mold. Place the extra soap into a separate mold to save it. The first few passes with the cardboard will be a little awkward and messy, but that’s okay!

* Continue sliding the tool through the mold. As you move the cardboard piece down the mold, lift it up and out and discard the excess soap. Continue to move the shaper down the length of the mold until you get about three-fourths of the way. Try your best to keep moving the carrot in the same spot over and over again, otherwise you’ll end up with a very wide carrot.

* Once you’re almost to the other end, move the shaper in the opposite direction. Keep moving the carrot back and forth until it’s no longer catching soap.

* Once you’re happy with the shape, it’s time to mix the remaining lye and oils. Pour the lye mixture into the oils and stick blend until you reach a thin trace.

* Add the 0.6 ounces of 10X Orange Essential Oil and mix in with the stick blender.

* Add 1.5 teaspoons of dispersed Nuclear Orange Pigment and 2 teaspoons orange peel powder. Use a whisk to mix in.

* Gently pour the orange soap into the negative space in the mold. Continue to pour until it’s level with the top of the brown soap on the sides.

* We had a little bit of orange soap leftover. We let it thicken slightly, and poured it down the middle of the orange layer to build it up in the center.

* Use a small spoon to smooth out the orange soap and create a rounded top. Don’t worry about it looking perfect. Set the soap aside while you prep the last batch.

Cold Process.name: Marseille Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["Olive Oil: 500g", "Tallow Beef: 500g", "Water: 300g", "Lye - NaOH: 134.87g", "Eucalyptus EO: 10 ML", "Rosemary EO: 5 ML", "Pine EO: 5 ML"]
Cold Process.instructions:
- Temps: 40°C (104°F)
- Unmold: 12-18 hours
- For Laundry Gel: 400 grams soap to 4 litres water
- For whites, add 1/2 - 1 cup sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) to the gel.

Cold Process.name: Rustic Clay Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["55% liquid oils", "20% beef tallow", "20% coconut oil (RBD)", "5% castor oil", "10g white kaolin clay", "5g sodium lactate", "5g French green clay"]
Cold Process.instructions:
Calculate your recipe for the amount of soap you’re making to get the finite amounts of the fats, lye, and water. Unsure about how to use SoapCalc? I made a video to walk you through it! The video tutorial for this soap also features a lot of details on how to calculate the soap and how to make it from start to finish.

Put on your safety gear; gloves + eye protection of course, and an apron is also a good idea.

Prepare your mould—I used the loaf mould my dad made me for this soap, but you could use a cavity mould if you prefer.

Melt your oils together in your soaping pot and let your oils cool to slightly warmer than room temperature. Mix up your lye water and let that cool to about room temperature (I always use ice for part of your water to speed up the cooling process).

Once the lye solution and the melted fats have cooled to slightly warmer than room temperature, you’re ready to get started!

Blend the kaolin clay into the fats, and stir the sodium lactate into the lye water. Gently pour the lye mixture to the melted fats. Bring the batter to a thin trace. Once you’ve reached a thin trace, pour about 1/4–1/3 of the batter into a second container/pot, and blend the French green clay into that part of the batter.

That’s it for the batter! Pour the kaolin clay part of the batter into the loaf mould, and then knock the mold on your countertop to even it out and work out some of the bubbles.

Gently spoon the green batter on top of the uncoloured batter, smooth, and sculpt the top as desired. Once you’ve sculpted the top (I did a bit of a mohawk with my spatula), leave it to saponify.

After about 36 hours the soap should be firm enough to slice (though depending on your mould you may want to freeze it first—I used a silicone mould and froze it to prevent denting, but I don’t think you’d need to if you used a brittle mold that you can deconstruct to remove the loaf). Unmould it, trim off any dangly bits, and slice away.

Leave the bars to age (aka dry) for 3–4 weeks before using. Enjoy!

Cold Process.name: The Beginner's Guide to Making CP Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH)", "Distilled Water", "Oils or Fats", "Fragrance (either Fragrance Oil or Essential Oil – optional)", "Pigment or other color additive (optional)"]
Cold Process.instructions:
Follow these steps to make your lye solution:

Slowly add the lye to the water

1.  Using your scale, take a heavy plastic, heat-resistant glass or stainless steel container and place it on the scale – thus giving you the weight of the container. (Use the same unit of measurement you used in the lye calculator – either ounces or grams)
2.  Once you have the weight of the empty container, press the "tare" button on your scale to return it to zero. You are now ready to measure your distilled water.
3.  SLOWLY pour the distilled water into the container on the scale until you reach your desired weight. Be accurate!
4.  Remove your water container from the scale and return the scale to zero (usually by hitting the “tare” button again)
5.  Place your sodium hydroxide container on the scale. Follow the same process you did for the water container, measuring the weight of the empty container first, then pressing "tare", to bring it back to zero.
6.  Next, take your sodium hydroxide and SLOWLY pour it into the container on the scale (You are wearing your gloves, right?) until you reach your desired weight.
7.  Next, in a well ventilated area, SLOWLY pour the sodium hydroxide into the water. **NOTE: Never pour water into sodium hydroxide!**
8.  Use your spatula to make sure the solution is well mixed. **Avoid breathing the fumes as much as possible.**
9.  The solution will heat up. Set aside and wait for it to cool to between 95°F and 105°F3.

While the lye solution is cooling you can prepare your other ingredients and materials.

Choose your fragrance (optional), color additives (optional) and/or any additives \*\*(link) that you will be incorporating. Get them out and set aside so they're ready.

During this time, also prepare your mold.

Next you need to combine your oils/fats in the soap pot. Depending on how many oils/fats you have, you may need to repeat these steps several times:

1.  Place an appropriately sized container for the first oil/fat on the scale and weigh it. Press the "tare" button to return the scale to zero.
2.  Slowly either scoop (for solid oils/fats) or pour your oil into the container to the desired weight.
3.  Pour the measured oil/fat into your stainless steel soap pot
4.  Repeat #1 - #3 for each oil/fat you have in your recipe.

If your recipe contains solid oils/fats, you will need to melt them. Place your pot on a heat source (either a stove or a hot plate) and turn it on to medium heat. Do not leave your pot unattended! You do not want to overheat or burn the oils, only gently melt them. Stirring gently usually helps to break up the big pieces of solid oils and speed along the process.

Once the oils mixture is melted, turn off your burner to allow the oils to cool down between 95°F and 105°F4.

While you are waiting for the oils and lye solution to cool, you can measure out your other ingredients. If you are not using fragrance, color or other additives, skip this step.

For each fragrance, color additive or other additive, place an appropriately sized container on the scale and weigh it. Press the "tare" button to return the scale to zero. Slowly pour/place your ingredient into the container until you reach the desired amount. Set aside.

NOTE: As a general rule of thumb, don't use more than about 0.6 ounces of fragrance per 1 pound of oil/fat in your recipe.

Use your digital thermometer to tell when your oil and lye solution have reached the desired temperature. Once they are ready, you can start the final phase (before the dishes, that is).

Make sure you have everything ready at your work station - your mold, oils, lye solution, and fragrance and/or other additives. Plug in your stick blender and make sure you have your safety equipment on (put it back on, you know you took it off when you were waiting for things to cool down).

Begin by pouring your lye solution slowly into your fats/oils and stirring with your whisk. Once all of the lye solution is in, scrape sides and stir with the spatula until everything is initially blended.

If you are using a stick blender, completely submerge it in the solution. If you used a big pot, you may have to tilt it to submerge the blender. Using short bursts, start to blend the solution, trying to get the edges and the bottom, completely mixing everything. Scrape down sides with the spatula to be sure no under mixed lye or oil remains.

SLOWLY pour the lye solution into the oils

Use a stick blender to mix the soap

If you're not using a stick blender, then just keep mixing and mixing by hand. It will work fine, but will take a while longer.

The solution will start to thicken as it saponifies (combines to become soap). Once it reaches "trace", you are ready to pour it into the soap mold. "Trace" is when the soap mixture is still thin enough to pour off a spoon, but thick enough to leave a "trace" on the top of the pot as it falls back in. It's about like cake batter.

Add any fragrance, color and/or other additives, using whisk or stick blender to incorporate fully.4

Trace

Pour the soap into your mold

Slowly pour the wet soap into the soap mold. Be sure to get all of the soap out of the pot, and get it into all of the corners of the mold. Once the pot is empty and your mold is filled, lightly tap the mold on the surface of your work station to make sure the soap is set and to release any trapped air. You can clean the edges of the soap mold if you wish, but it is not necessary.

Wrap or cover the mold with a heavy blanket or towel to contain the head and allow it to rest and cure for 12-24 hours. It will get quite warm and then cool down. That is the saponification process taking place. Once the soap is fully cooled, you can unmold it.

Depending on your oils and water content, the soap may be soft when unmolded. Allow soap to rest until it is hardened up a bit (1 - 3 days) and then cut it as desired. Set aside in a cool area with good circulation for 4 - 6 weeks until the bars are fully hard.

Congratulations! You just made your first batch of cold process soap!

Cold Process.name: Calendula, Chamomile, and Comfrey Soap
Cold Process.ingredients: ["2/3 cup olive oil", "2/3 cup coconut oil", "2/3 cup vegetable oil blend (I use a combination of grapeseed, safflower, and sunflower oils)", "3/4 cup cold chamomile tea", "1/4 cup lye – also called 100% sodium hydroxide", "1 teaspoon dried calendula petals", "1 teaspoon dried chamomile flowers", "1 teaspoon dried ground comfrey root or leaves"]
Cold Process.instructions:
1. Prepare the lye with the tea as you would with water, set aside until the temperature reaches 100°F or near there. 
2. Combine all the oils and heat just enough to melt the coconut oil, until the temp reaches 100°.
3. Slowly mix the lye into the oils and stir for 5 minutes. 
4. After 5 minutes, you can keep stirring or use an immersion blender until it thickens, much like pudding. This is the “trace” stage. 
5. At trace, add dried calendula petals, dried chamomile flowers, and dried ground comfrey root or leaves. *Note: All of your plant material must be dried or it can cause spoilage in your soaps.*
6. Stir well to incorporate, and pour into molds. 
7. Remove from the molds after 24 hours, cut into smaller bars if you used a large mold, and cure for 3-4 weeks.

Bath Bombs.name: Lavender Fields Bliss Bath Bomb
Bath Bombs.instructions:
1. In a mixing bowl, combine baking soda, citric acid, Epsom salt, and cornstarch.
2. Add almond oil, lavender buds, and lavender essential oil. Mix well until the mixture resembles wet sand.
3. Pack the mixture into bath bomb molds and let them dry for 24 hours.
4. Once dry, remove from molds and store in an airtight container.
Bath Bombs.benefits: Lavender is known for its relaxing properties, helping to calm the mind and body. This bath bomb is perfect for unwinding after a long day and promoting a sense of peace and tranquility.

Bath Bombs.name: Rose Petal Romance Bath Bomb
Bath Bombs.instructions:
1. Combine baking soda, citric acid, Epsom salt, and cornstarch in a mixing bowl.
2. Add almond oil, dried rose petals, and rose essential oil. Mix until the mixture holds together when squeezed.
3. Pack the mixture into molds and let them dry for 24 hours.
4. Once dry, remove from molds and store in a cool, dry place.
Bath Bombs.benefits: Rose essential oil is known for its romantic and calming properties. This bath bomb creates a luxurious bathing experience, leaving the skin soft and delicately scented.

1. Combine baking soda, citric acid, Epsom salt, and cornstarch in a mixing bowl.

3. Pack the mixture into molds and let them dry for 24 hours.
4. Once dry, remove from molds and store in an airtight container.
Bath Bombs.benefits: The chamomile in this bath bomb is known for its calming and relaxing properties, making it ideal for a soothing bath before bedtime.

3. Combine the wet and dry ingredients until well incorporated.
4. Press the mixture into molds and let them dry for 24 hours.
5. Once dry, remove from molds and store in an airtight container.
Bath Bombs.benefits: Vanilla has a comforting and calming scent, promoting relaxation and reducing anxiety. Shea butter adds moisturizing properties, leaving the skin soft and hydrated.
